sub_topic: Calculation of the electrical conductivity of a metal
message_1: Calculate the electrical conductivity of a copper wire of length 2 meters and cross-sectional area of 3 mm², at a temperature of 25 °C, given that the resistivity of copper at this temperature is 1.68 × 10⁻⁸ Ω·m.
message_2:
To calculate the electrical conductivity of the copper wire, we first need to find its resistance using the formula:

Resistance (R) = Resistivity (ρ) × Length (L) / Cross-sectional Area (A)

Given:
Resistivity (ρ) = 1.68 × 10⁻⁸ Ω·m
Length (L) = 2 meters
Cross-sectional Area (A) = 3 mm² = 3 × 10⁻⁶ m² (converting to square meters)

Now, we can calculate the resistance:

R = (1.68 × 10⁻⁸ Ω·m) × (2 m) / (3 × 10⁻⁶ m²)
R = 3.36 × 10⁻⁸ Ω·m / 3 × 10⁻⁶ m²
R = 1.12 × 10⁻² Ω

Now that we have the resistance, we can find the electrical conductivity (σ) using the formula:

Conductivity (σ) = 1 / Resistivity (ρ)

Since we know the resistivity of copper at 25 °C:

σ = 1 / (1.68 × 10⁻⁸ Ω·m)
σ ≈ 5.95 × 10⁷ S/m (Siemens per meter)

So, the electrical conductivity of the copper wire at 25 °C is approximately 5.95 × 10⁷ S/m.
